question: He is blessed who is assured that the animal is dying out in him [MASK] by day, and the divine being established.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: By turns our purity inspires and our impurity casts us down.

question: Do not stay to be an overseer of the poor, but endeavor to become one of the worthies of the [MASK].

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: If, then, we would indeed restore mankind by truly Indian, botanic, magnetic, or natural means, let us first be as simple and well as Nature ourselves, dispel the clouds which hang over our own brows, and take up a little life into our pores.

question: Let the [MASK] rumble; what if it threaten ruin to farmersâ crops?
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Grow wild according to thy nature, like these sedges and brakes, which will never become English hay.

question: The dead and for the most part unmerchantable wood behind my house, and the driftwood from the pond, have supplied the [MASK] of my fuel.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I got out several cords of stumps in ploughing, which supplied me with fuel for a long time, and left small circles of virgin mould, easily distinguishable through the summer by the greater luxuriance of the beans there.
next_sentence: I was obliged to hire a team and a man for the ploughing, though I held the plough myself.

question: They force me to [MASK] like themselves.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: They only can force me who obey a higher law than I.
next_sentence: I do not hear of men being forced to live this way or that by masses of men.

question: Signs were hung out on all sides to allure him; some to catch him by the appetite, as the [MASK] and victualling cellar; some by the fancy, as the dry goods store and the jewellerâs; and others by the hair or the feet or the skirts, as the barber, the shoemaker, or the tailor.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Of course, those who were stationed nearest to the head of the line, where they could most see and be seen, and have the first blow at him, paid the highest prices for their places; and the few straggling inhabitants in the outskirts, where long gaps in the line began to occur, and the traveller could get over walls or turn aside into cow paths, and so escape, paid a very slight ground or window tax.
next_sentence: Besides, there was a still more terrible standing invitation to call at every one of these houses, and company expected about these times.

question: coincident with the [MASK] of wells of tears.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: What a sorrowful act must that be,âthe covering up of wells!
next_sentence: These cellar dents, like deserted fox burrows, old holes, are all that is left where once were the stir and bustle of human life, and âfate, free-will, foreknowledge absolute,â in some form and dialect or other were by turns discussed.

question: For a moment compassion restrained the latterâs arm; but that was a short-lived mood, and as quick as thought can follow thought his piece was levelled, and whang! âthe fox rolling over the rock lay dead on the [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: For a long time he stood still and listened to their music, so sweet to a hunterâs ear, when suddenly the fox appeared, threading the solemn aisles with an easy coursing pace, whose sound was concealed by a sympathetic rustle of the leaves, swift and still, keeping the ground, leaving his pursuers far behind; and, leaping upon a rock amid the woods, he sat erect and listening, with his back to the hunter.
next_sentence: The hunter still kept his place and listened to the hounds.

question: Viewed from a hill-top it reflects the color of the sky; but near at hand it is of a yellowish tint next the shore where you can see the sand, then a [MASK] green, which gradually deepens to a uniform dark green in the body of the pond.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Lying between the earth and the heavens, it partakes of the color of both.
next_sentence: In some lights, viewed even from a hill-top, it is of a vivid green next the shore.

question: The pond began to boom about an hour after sunrise, when it felt the influence of the sunâs rays slanted upon it from over the [MASK]; it stretched itself and yawned like a waking man with a gradually increasing tumult, which was kept up three or four hours.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: One pleasant morning after a cold night, February 24th, 1850, having gone to Flintâs Pond to spend the day, I noticed with surprise, that when I struck the ice with the head of my axe, it resounded like a gong for many rods around, or as if I had struck on a tight drum-head.
next_sentence: It took a short siesta at noon, and boomed once more toward night, as the sun was withdrawing his influence.

question: Let us [MASK] who is the strongest.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I will breathe after my own fashion.
next_sentence: What force has a multitude?

question: These forms are more agreeable to the fancy and imagination than [MASK] paintings or other the most expensive furniture.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Should not every apartment in which man dwells be lofty enough to create some obscurity over-head, where flickering shadows may play at evening about the rafters?
next_sentence: I now first began to inhabit my house, I may say, when I began to use it for warmth as well as shelter.

question: Thus we kept on like true idealists, rejecting the evidence of our senses, until at a turn in the road we heard the crackling and actually [MASK] the heat of the fire from over the wall, and realized, alas!
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: And then fresh sparks went up above the wood, as if the roof fell in, and we all shouted âConcord to the rescue!â Wagons shot past with furious speed and crushing loads, bearing, perchance, among the rest, the agent of the Insurance Company, who was bound to go however far; and ever and anon the engine bell tinkled behind, more slow and sure; and rearmost of all, as it was afterward whispered, came they who set the fire and gave the alarm.
next_sentence: that we were there.

question: The soil is blanched and accursed there, and before that becomes necessary the [MASK] itself will be destroyed.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Deliver me from a city built on the site of a more ancient city, whose materials are ruins, whose gardens cemeteries.
next_sentence: With such reminiscences I repeopled the woods and lulled myself asleep.

question: Of a life of luxury the fruit is luxury, whether in [MASK], or commerce, or literature, or art.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: None can be an impartial or wise observer of human life but from the vantage ground of what we should call voluntary poverty.
next_sentence: There are nowadays professors of philosophy, but not philosophers.

question: They are not like cups between the hills; for this one, which is so unusually deep for its area, appears in a vertical section through its centre not deeper than a [MASK] plate.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: But the deepest ponds are not so deep in proportion to their area as most suppose, and, if drained, would not leave very remarkable valleys.
next_sentence: Most ponds, emptied, would leave a meadow no more hollow than we frequently see.

question: The future inhabitants of this region, wherever they may [MASK] their houses, may be sure that they have been anticipated.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Well, there I might live, I said; and there I did live, for an hour, a summer and a winter life; saw how I could let the years run off, buffet the winter through, and see the spring come in.
next_sentence: An afternoon sufficed to lay out the land into orchard, woodlot, and pasture, and to decide what fine oaks or pines should be left to stand before the door, and whence each blasted tree could be seen to the best advantage; and then I let it lie, fallow perchance, for a man is rich in proportion to the number of things which he can afford to let alone.

question: It may be [MASK] into every language, and not only be read but actually breathed from all human lips; ânot be represented on canvas or in marble only, but be carved out of the breath of life itself.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It is the work of art nearest to life itself.
next_sentence: The symbol of an ancient manâs thought becomes a modern manâs speech.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I think that I am near the end of it.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It is partly his taste, and not merely his misfortune.
next_sentence: I was wont to pity the clumsy Irish laborers who cut ice on the pond, in such mean and ragged clothes, while I shivered in my more tidy and somewhat more fashionable garments, till, one bitter cold day, one who had slipped into the water came to my house to warm him, and I saw him strip off three pairs of pants and two pairs of stockings ere he got down to the skin, though they were dirty and ragged enough, it is true, and that he could afford to refuse the extra garments which I offered him, he had so many intra ones.

question: Who knows but if our instruments were delicate enough we might [MASK] an undulation in the crust of the earth?

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It was probably greater in the middle.
next_sentence: When two legs of my level were on the shore and the third on the ice, and the sights were directed over the latter, a rise or fall of the ice of an almost infinitesimal amount made a difference of several feet on a tree across the pond.

question: The character of the voters is not [MASK].

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience

next_sentence: I cast my vote, perchance, as I think right; but I am not vitally concerned that that right should prevail.

question: As if that were important, and there were not enough to [MASK] you without them.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience

next_sentence: As if Nature could support but one order of understandings, could not sustain birds as well as quadrupeds, flying as well as creeping things, and hush and who, which Bright can understand, were the best English.

question: Nothing so fair, so pure, and at the same time so large, as a lake, [MASK], lies on the surface of the earth.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: In such a day, in September or October, Walden is a perfect forest mirror, set round with stones as precious to my eye as if fewer or rarer.
next_sentence: Sky water.

question: Those things for which the most money is demanded are never the things which the [MASK] most wants.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Those conveniences which the student requires at Cambridge or elsewhere cost him or somebody else ten times as great a sacrifice of life as they would with proper management on both sides.
next_sentence: Tuition, for instance, is an important item in the term bill, while for the far more valuable education which he gets by associating with the most cultivated of his contemporaries no charge is made.

question: You may perhaps have some pleasant, thrilling, [MASK] hours, even in a poor-house.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Love your life, poor as it is.
next_sentence: The setting sun is reflected from the windows of the alms-house as brightly as from the rich manâs abode; the snow melts before its door as early in the spring.

question: His white breast, the stillness of the [MASK], and the smoothness of the water were all against him.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Though the sky was by this time overcast, the pond was so smooth that I could see where he broke the surface when I did not hear him.
next_sentence: At length, having come up fifty rods off, he uttered one of those prolonged howls, as if calling on the god of loons to aid him, and immediately there came a wind from the east and rippled the surface, and filled the whole air with misty rain, and I was impressed as if it were the prayer of the loon answered, and his god was angry with me; and so I left him disappearing far away on the tumultuous surface.

question: First look out for [MASK], and supply vacancies by planting anew.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Plant the common small white bush bean about the first of June, in rows three feet by eighteen inches apart, being careful to select fresh round and unmixed seed.
next_sentence: Then look out for woodchucks, if it is an exposed place, for they will nibble off the earliest tender leaves almost clean as they go; and again, when the young tendrils make their appearance, they have notice of it, and will shear them off with both buds and young pods, sitting erect like a squirrel.

question: God is alone, âbut the devil, he is far from being alone; he sees a [MASK] deal of company; he is legion.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The sun is alone, except in thick weather, when there sometimes appear to be two, but one is a mock sun.
next_sentence: I am no more lonely than a single mullein or dandelion in a pasture, or a bean leaf, or sorrel, or a horse-fly, or a bumble-bee.

question: It is reptile and sensual, and perhaps cannot be [MASK] expelled; like the worms which, even in life and health, occupy our bodies.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: We are conscious of an animal in us, which awakens in proportion as our higher nature slumbers.
next_sentence: Possibly we may withdraw from it, but never change its nature.

question: There came to me in this case a melody which the air had strained, and which had conversed with every leaf and needle of the wood, that portion of the sound which the elements had taken up and modulated and [MASK] from vale to vale.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: All sound heard at the greatest possible distance produces one and the same effect, a vibration of the universal lyre, just as the intervening atmosphere makes a distant ridge of earth interesting to our eyes by the azure tint it imparts to it.
next_sentence: The echo is, to some extent, an original sound, and therein is the magic and charm of it.

question: By turns our purity [MASK] and our impurity casts us down.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Man flows at once to God when the channel of purity is open.
next_sentence: He is blessed who is assured that the animal is dying out in him day by day, and the divine being established.

question: The intellect is a [MASK]; it discerns and rifts its way into the secret of things.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I have always been regretting that I was not as wise as the day I was born.
next_sentence: I do not wish to be any more busy with my hands than is necessary.

question: Some are accustomed to speak of deep and dangerous holes even in quiet sandy ponds like this, but the effect of water under these [MASK] is to level all inequalities.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: In one instance, on a line arbitrarily chosen, the depth did not vary more than one foot in thirty rods; and generally, near the middle, I could calculate the variation for each one hundred feet in any direction beforehand within three or four inches.
next_sentence: The regularity of the bottom and its conformity to the shores and the range of the neighboring hills were so perfect that a distant promontory betrayed itself in the soundings quite across the pond, and its direction could be determined by observing the opposite shore.

question: The amount of it is, if a man is alive, there is always danger that he may die, though the danger must be allowed to be less in proportion as he is dead-and-alive to [MASK] with.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: To them the village was literally a com-munity, a league for mutual defence, and you would suppose that they would not go a-huckleberrying without a medicine chest.
next_sentence: A man sits as many risks as he runs.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: (Lepus, levipes, light-foot, some think.)

question: There was a stove, a bed, and a place to sit, an infant in the house where it was born, a silk parasol, gilt-framed looking-glass, and a patent new coffee [MASK] nailed to an oak sapling, all told.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The hunter still kept his place and listened to the hounds.
next_sentence: At length the old hound burst into view with muzzle to the ground, and snapping the air as if possessed, and ran directly to the rock; but spying the dead fox she suddenly ceased her hounding as if struck dumb with amazement, and walked round and round him in silence; and one by one her pups arrived, and, like their mother, were sobered into silence by the mystery.

question: Nevertheless, it stood through a [MASK] many hasty-puddings.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience

next_sentence: I did not plaster till it was freezing weather.

question: The more you think of it, the less the [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I was myself excited somewhat even as if they had been men.
next_sentence: And certainly there is not the fight recorded in Concord history, at least, if in the history of America, that will bear a momentâs comparison with this, whether for the numbers engaged in it, or for the patriotism and heroism displayed.

question: It certainly is fair to look at that class by whose labor the works which [MASK] this generation are accomplished.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: To know this I should not need to look farther than to the shanties which every where border our railroads, that last improvement in civilization; where I see in my daily walks human beings living in sties, and all winter with an open door, for the sake of light, without any visible, often imaginable, wood pile, and the forms of both old and young are permanently contracted by the long habit of shrinking from cold and misery, and the development of all their limbs and faculties is checked.
next_sentence: Such too, to a greater or less extent, is the condition of the operatives of every denomination in England, which is the great workhouse of the world.

question: Give me a hammer, and [MASK] me feel for the furring.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I would not be one of those who will foolishly drive a nail into mere lath and plastering; such a deed would keep me awake nights.
next_sentence: Do not depend on the putty.

question: It [MASK] that from such a basis of truth and frankness as the poor weak-headed pauper had laid, our intercourse might go forward to something better than the intercourse of sages.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I did not know at first but it was the result of a wise policy.

question: They were not time [MASK] from my life, but so much over and above my usual allowance.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I grew in those seasons like corn in the night, and they were far better than any work of the hands would have been.
next_sentence: I realized what the Orientals mean by contemplation and the forsaking of works.

question: They are all on a committee of arrangements, and hourly expect a [MASK] from somebody.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: What are men celebrating?
next_sentence: God is only the president of the day, and Webster is his orator.

question: Look at a meeting-house, or a court-house, or a jail, or a shop, or a dwelling-house, and say what that thing really is before a [MASK] gaze, and they would all go to pieces in your account of them.

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: If he should give us an account of the realities he beheld there, we should not recognize the place in his description.
next_sentence: Men esteem truth remote, in the outskirts of the system, behind the farthest star, before Adam and after the last man.

question: Is this owing to the generosity of him in whose possession it is [MASK], or to the remissness of the officers of justice?

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Society recovers only a tenth part of the property then.
next_sentence: Philanthropy is almost the only virtue which is sufficiently appreciated by mankind.

question: The fault-finder will find faults even in [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It looks poorest when you are richest.
next_sentence: Love your life, poor as it is.

question: If it is necessary, omit one bridge over the river, go round a little there, and throw one [MASK] at least over the darker gulf of ignorance which surrounds us.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Instead of noblemen, let us have noble villages of men.
next_sentence: Sounds  But while we are confined to books, though the most select and classic, and read only particular written languages, which are themselves but dialects and provincial, we are in danger of forgetting the language which all things and events speak without metaphor, which alone is copious and standard.

question: The whole bank, which is from twenty to forty feet high, is sometimes overlaid with a mass of this kind of foliage, or sandy rupture, for a quarter of a mile on one or both sides, the produce of one spring [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: When the flowing mass reaches the drain at the foot of the bank it spreads out flatter into strands, the separate streams losing their semi-cylindrical form and gradually becoming more flat and broad, running together as they are more moist, till they form an almost flat sand, still variously and beautifully shaded, but in which you can trace the original forms of vegetation; till at length, in the water itself, they are converted into banks, like those formed off the mouths of rivers, and the forms of vegetation are lost in the ripple marks on the bottom.
next_sentence: What makes this sand foliage remarkable is its springing into existence thus suddenly.

question: The best works of art are the expression of manâs struggle to free himself from this condition, but the effect of our art is merely to make this low state comfortable and that [MASK] state to be forgotten.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: We have built for this world a family mansion, and for the next a family tomb.
next_sentence: There is actually no place in this village for a work of fine art, if any had come down to us, to stand, for our lives, our houses and streets, furnish no proper pedestal for it.

question: They preserve their form when dry for an [MASK] period.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Moreover, the waves, I suspect, do not so much construct as wear down a material which has already acquired consistency.
next_sentence: Flintâs Pond! Such is the poverty of our nomenclature.

question: Why should we [MASK] under and go with the stream?
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Let us rise early and fast, or break fast, gently and without perturbation; let company come and let company go, let the bells ring and the children cry,âdetermined to make a day of it.
next_sentence: Let us not be upset and overwhelmed in that terrible rapid and whirlpool called a dinner, situated in the meridian shallows.

question: In one direction from my house there was a colony of muskrats in the river meadows; under the grove of elms and buttonwoods in the other horizon was a village of busy men, as [MASK] to me as if they had been prairie dogs, each sitting at the mouth of its burrow, or running over to a neighborâs to gossip.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: As I walked in the woods to see the birds and squirrels, so I walked in the village to see the men and boys; instead of the wind among the pines I heard the carts rattle.
next_sentence: I went there frequently to observe their habits.

question: Their fidelity and sagacity are below [MASK] now.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Their vocation, too, is gone.
next_sentence: They will slink back to their kennels in disgrace, or perchance run wild and strike a league with the wolf and the fox.

question: There we sat together under that [MASK] of the roof which leaked the least, while it showered and thundered without.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: But therein, as I found, dwelt now John Field, an Irishman, and his wife, and several children, from the broad-faced boy who assisted his father at his work, and now came running by his side from the bog to escape the rain, to the wrinkled, sibyl-like, cone-headed infant that sat upon its fatherâs knee as in the palaces of nobles, and looked out from its home in the midst of wet and hunger inquisitively upon the stranger, with the privilege of infancy, not knowing but it was the last of a noble line, and the hope and cynosure of the world, instead of John Fieldâs poor starveling brat.
next_sentence: I had sat there many times of old before the ship was built that floated his family to America.

question: It was dark, and had a dirt floor for the most part, dank, clammy, and aguish, only here a board and there a [MASK] which would not bear removal.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The hens were driven in by my approach.
next_sentence: She lighted a lamp to show me the inside of the roof and the walls, and also that the board floor extended under the bed, warning me not to step into the cellar, a sort of dust hole two feet deep.

question: May be they are simply great enough to [MASK] without misgiving.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The townâs poor seem to me often to live the most independent lives of any.
next_sentence: Most think that they are above being supported by the town; but it oftener happens that they are not above supporting themselves by dishonest means, which should be more disreputable.

question: These lend a pleasing [MASK] to the bottom.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Perhaps they are the nests of the chivin.
next_sentence: The shore is irregular enough not to be monotonous.

question: Suddenly an influx of light filled my house, though the evening was at hand, and the clouds of winter still overhung it, and the [MASK] were dripping with sleety rain.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It is seemingly instantaneous at last.
next_sentence: I looked out the window, and lo!

question: Are we sure that there is none of it in our own [MASK]?

title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: What is the nature of the luxury which enervates and destroys nations?
next_sentence: The philosopher is in advance of his age even in the outward form of his life.

question: He is more indigenous even than the [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: All climates agree with brave Chanticleer.
next_sentence: His health is ever good, his lungs are sound, his spirits never flag.

question: Old [MASK] for old people, and new deeds for new.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: What old people say you cannot do you try and find that you can.
next_sentence: Old people did not know enough once, perchance, to fetch fresh fuel to keep the fire a-going; new people put a little dry wood under a pot, and are whirled round the globe with the speed of birds, in a way to kill old people, as the phrase is.

question: The whistle of the locomotive penetrates my woods summer and winter, sounding like the scream of a hawk sailing over some farmerâs yard, informing me that many restless city merchants are arriving within the [MASK] of the town, or adventurous country traders from the other side.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I too would fain be a track-repairer somewhere in the orbit of the earth.
next_sentence: As they come under one horizon, they shout their warning to get off the track to the other, heard sometimes through the circles of two towns.

question: These nuts, as far as they went, were a good [MASK] for bread.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I relinquished these trees to them and visited the more distant woods composed wholly of chestnut.
next_sentence: Many other substitutes might, perhaps, be found.

question: Who does not [MASK] the interest with which when young he looked at shelving rocks, or any approach to a cave?
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It plays house, as well as horse, having an instinct for it.
next_sentence: It was the natural yearning of that portion of our most primitive ancestor which still survived in us.

question: Yet such as these even are [MASK] esteemed good citizens.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: They have the same sort of worth only as horses and dogs.
next_sentence: Others, as most legislators, politicians, lawyers, ministers, and office-holders, serve the state chiefly with their heads; and, as they rarely make any moral distinctions, they are as likely to serve the devil, without intending it, as God.

question: The dinner even is only the parable of a [MASK], commonly.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: It would seem as if the very language of our parlors would lose all its nerve and degenerate into palaver wholly, our lives pass at such remoteness from its symbols, and its metaphors and tropes are necessarily so far fetched, through slides and dumb-waiters, as it were; in other words, the parlor is so far from the kitchen and workshop.
next_sentence: As if only the savage dwelt near enough to Nature and Truth to borrow a trope from them.

question: She spins and weaves and cuts with full [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: We worship not the Graces, nor the ParcÃ¦, but Fashion.
next_sentence: The head monkey at Paris puts on a travellerâs cap, and all the monkeys in America do the same.

question: Who has not seen a salt fish, thoroughly [MASK] for this world, so that nothing can spoil it, and putting the perseverance of the saints to the blush?
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: This closed car smells of salt fish, the strong New England and commercial scent, reminding me of the Grand Banks and the fisheries.
next_sentence: with which you may sweep or pave the streets, and split your kindlings, and the teamster shelter himself and his lading against sun wind and rain behind it,âand the trader, as a Concord trader once did, hang it up by his door for a sign when he commences business, until at last his oldest customer cannot tell surely whether it be animal, vegetable, or mineral, and yet it shall be as pure as a snowflake, and if it be put into a pot and boiled, will come out an excellent dun fish for a Saturdayâs dinner.

question: He dwelt, as it were, in a tent in this world, and was either threading the valleys, or crossing the plains, or climbing the mountain [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: When he was refreshed with food and sleep he contemplated his journey again.
next_sentence: But lo!

question: Indeed, they sometimes dive below this line, as it were by [MASK], and are undeceived.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: You would think that you could walk dry under it to the opposite hills, and that the swallows which skim over might perch on it.
next_sentence: As you look over the pond westward you are obliged to employ both your hands to defend your eyes against the reflected as well as the true sun, for they are equally bright; and if, between the two, you survey its surface critically, it is literally as smooth as glass, except where the skater insects, at equal intervals scattered over its whole extent, by their motions in the sun produce the finest imaginable sparkle on it, or, perchance, a duck plumes itself, or, as I have said, a swallow skims so low as to touch it.

question: The moles nested in my [MASK], nibbling every third potato, and making a snug bed even there of some hair left after plastering and of brown paper; for even the wildest animals love comfort and warmth as well as man, and they survive the winter only because they are so careful to secure them.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: But my house occupied so sunny and sheltered a position, and its roof was so low, that I could afford to let the fire go out in the middle of almost any winter day.
next_sentence: Some of my friends spoke as if I was coming to the woods on purpose to freeze myself.

question: They [MASK] also behind my house, and one large tree, which almost overshadowed it, was, when in flower, a bouquet which scented the whole neighborhood, but the squirrels and the jays got most of its fruit; the last coming in flocks early in the morning and picking the nuts out of the burrs before they fell.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Occasionally I climbed and shook the trees.
next_sentence: I relinquished these trees to them and visited the more distant woods composed wholly of chestnut.

question: The place where that may occur is always the same, and indescribably [MASK] to all our senses.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Any prospect of awakening or coming to life to a dead man makes indifferent all times and places.
next_sentence: For the most part we allow only outlying and transient circumstances to make our occasions.

question: And every few years a new lot is laid down and [MASK] over; so that, if some have the pleasure of riding on a rail, others have the misfortune to be ridden upon.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: They are sound sleepers, I assure you.
next_sentence: And when they run over a man that is walking in his sleep, a supernumerary sleeper in the wrong position, and wake him up, they suddenly stop the cars, and make a hue and cry about it, as if this were an exception.

question: This is a remarkable depth for so small an area; yet not an inch of it can be spared by the [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The greatest depth was exactly one hundred and two feet; to which may be added the five feet which it has risen since, making one hundred and seven.
next_sentence: What if all ponds were shallow?

question: All voting is a sort of gaming, like chequers or backgammon, with a slight [MASK] tinge to it, a playing with right and wrong, with moral questions; and betting naturally accompanies it.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: There are nine hundred and ninety-nine patrons of virtue to one virtuous man; but it is easier to deal with the real possessor of a thing than with the temporary guardian of it.
next_sentence: The character of the voters is not staked.

question: There are a thousand hacking at the branches of evil to one who is striking at the root, and it may be that he who bestows the largest amount of time and money on the needy is doing the most by his [MASK] of life to produce that misery which he strives in vain to relieve.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Then I began to pity myself, and I saw that it would be a greater charity to bestow on me a flannel shirt than a whole slop-shop on him.
next_sentence: It is the pious slave-breeder devoting the proceeds of every tenth slave to buy a Sundayâs liberty for the rest.

question: Sympathy with the fluttering alder and [MASK] leaves almost takes away my breath; yet, like the lake, my serenity is rippled but not ruffled.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The bullfrogs trump to usher in the night, and the note of the whippoorwill is borne on the rippling wind from over the water.
next_sentence: These small waves raised by the evening wind are as remote from storm as the smooth reflecting surface.

question: He had long ago bought a potterâs wheel of him, and [MASK] to know what had become of him.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: One day in midsummer, when I was hoeing, a man who was carrying a load of pottery to market stopped his horse against my field and inquired concerning Wyman the younger.
next_sentence: I had read of the potterâs clay and wheel in Scripture, but it had never occurred to me that the pots we use were not such as had come down unbroken from those days, or grown on trees like gourds somewhere, and I was pleased to hear that so fictile an art was ever practiced in my neighborhood.

question: Webster never goes behind government, and so cannot speak with [MASK] about it.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: They are wont to forget that the world is not governed by policy and expediency.
next_sentence: His words are wisdom to those legislators who contemplate no essential reform in the existing government; but for thinkers, and those who legislate for all time, he never once glances at the subject.

question: But alert and healthy natures remember that the [MASK] rose clear.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Yet they honestly think there is no choice left.
next_sentence: It is never too late to give up our prejudices.

question: And when they [MASK] over a man that is walking in his sleep, a supernumerary sleeper in the wrong position, and wake him up, they suddenly stop the cars, and make a hue and cry about it, as if this were an exception.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: And every few years a new lot is laid down and run over; so that, if some have the pleasure of riding on a rail, others have the misfortune to be ridden upon.
next_sentence: I am glad to know that it takes a gang of men for every five miles to keep the sleepers down and level in their beds as it is, for this is a sign that they may sometime get up again.

question: Such command no more respect than men of straw, or a [MASK] of dirt.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: They are the standing army, and the militia, jailers, constables, posse comitatus, &c. In most cases there is no free exercise whatever of the judgment or of the moral sense; but they put themselves on a level with wood and earth and stones; and wooden men can perhaps be manufactured that will serve the purpose as well.
next_sentence: They have the same sort of worth only as horses and dogs.

question: He had soaked hemlock leaves in [MASK] and drank it, and thought that was better than water in warm weather.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Did this country afford any beverage beside water?
next_sentence: When I asked him if he could do without money, he showed the convenience of money in such a way as to suggest and coincide with the most philosophical accounts of the origin of this institution, and the very derivation of the word pecunia.

question: He will put some things behind, will pass an invisible boundary; [MASK], universal, and more liberal laws will begin to establish themselves around and within him; or the old laws be expanded, and interpreted in his favor in a more liberal sense, and he will live with the license of a higher order of beings.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: I learned this, at least, by my experiment; that if one advances confidently in the direction of his dreams, and endeavors to live the life which he has imagined, he will meet with a success unexpected in common hours.
next_sentence: In proportion as he simplifies his life, the laws of the universe will appear less complex, and solitude will not be solitude, nor poverty poverty, nor weakness weakness.

question: If the condition of things which we were made for is not yet, what were any [MASK] which we can substitute?
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Shall he turn his spring into summer?
next_sentence: We will not be shipwrecked on a vain reality.

question: Even when cleft or [MASK] through it is not comprehended in its entireness.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The particular laws are as our points of view, as, to the traveller, a mountain outline varies with every step, and it has an infinite number of profiles, though absolutely but one form.
next_sentence: What I have observed of the pond is no less true in ethics.

question: One evening one sat by my door two paces from me, at first trembling with fear, [MASK] unwilling to move; a poor wee thing, lean and bony, with ragged ears and sharp nose, scant tail and slender paws.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Near at hand they only excited my pity.
next_sentence: It looked as if Nature no longer contained the breed of nobler bloods, but stood on her last toes.

question: When the reptile is attacked at one mouth of his [MASK], he shows himself at another.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: The impure can neither stand nor sit with purity.
next_sentence: If you would be chaste, you must be temperate.

question: So the [MASK] comes out of the mud with quakings of the earth.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: When the warmer days come, they who dwell near the river hear the ice crack at night with a startling whoop as loud as artillery, as if its icy fetters were rent from end to end, and within a few days see it rapidly going out.
next_sentence: One old man, who has been a close observer of Nature, and seems as thoroughly wise in regard to all her operations as if she had been put upon the stocks when he was a boy, and he had helped to lay her keel,âwho has come to his growth, and can hardly acquire more of natural lore if he should live to the age of Methuselah,âtold me, and I was surprised to hear him express wonder at any of Natureâs operations, for I thought that there were no secrets between them, that one spring day he took his gun and boat, and thought that he would have a little sport with the ducks.

question: We should live in all the [MASK] of the world in an hour; ay, in all the worlds of the ages.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Could a greater miracle take place than for us to look through each otherâs eyes for an instant?
next_sentence: History, Poetry, Mythology!âI know of no reading of anotherâs experience so startling and informing as this would be.

question: Moral reform is the effort to throw off [MASK].
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Morning is when I am awake and there is a dawn in me.
next_sentence: Why is it that men give so poor an account of their day if they have not been slumbering?

question: The setting [MASK] is reflected from the windows of the alms-house as brightly as from the rich manâs abode; the snow melts before its door as early in the spring.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: You may perhaps have some pleasant, thrilling, glorious hours, even in a poor-house.
next_sentence: I do not see but a quiet mind may live as contentedly there, and have as cheering thoughts, as in a palace.

question: Men paid him wages for work, and so helped to feed and clothe him; but he never exchanged [MASK] with them.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: He would not play any part.
next_sentence: He was so simply and naturally humbleâif he can be called humble who never aspiresâthat humility was no distinct quality in him, nor could he conceive of it.

question: She is not afraid to [MASK] herself to them.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Fishermen, hunters, woodchoppers, and others, spending their lives in the fields and woods, in a peculiar sense a part of Nature themselves, are often in a more favorable mood for observing her, in the intervals of their pursuits, than philosophers or poets even, who approach her with expectation.
next_sentence: The traveller on the prairie is naturally a hunter, on the head waters of the Missouri and Columbia a trapper, and at the Falls of St. Mary a fisherman.

question: You will in the mean while have earned your [MASK], and arrive there some time to-morrow, or possibly this evening, if you are lucky enough to get a job in season.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: Well, I start now on foot, and get there before night; I have travelled at that rate by the week together.
next_sentence: Instead of going to Fitchburg, you will be working here the greater part of the day.

question: He shared with me the [MASK] of cooking.
source_info: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience by Thoreau, Henry D. (Henry David)
title: Walden, and On The Duty Of Civil Disobedience
prev_sentence: He brought his own knife, though I had two, and we used to scour them by thrusting them into the earth.
next_sentence: I was pleased to see my work rising so square and solid by degrees, and reflected, that, if it proceeded slowly, it was calculated to endure a long time.
